facts.text: This is Criminal Appeal No. 22 of 1954.

anchor.surface_text: Appeal No. 22 of 1954. 1446 Appeal under Article 134 1   c

facts.text: Appeal under Article 134(1)(c) of the Constitution from the Judgment and Order dated 27th October 1953 of the Allahabad High Court in Criminal Reference No. 121 of 1953.

anchor.surface_text: Appeal under Article 134 1   c  of the Constitution from the Judgment and Order dated the 27th October 1953 of the Allahabad High Court in Criminal Reference No. 121 of 1953. P. Gupta and A. D. Mathur, for the appellant.

facts.text: Leave to appeal granted by the High Court of Allahabad.

anchor.surface_text: This is an appeal by leave granted by the High Court of Allahabad presumably under article 134 1  c  of the Constitution. The facts are simple.

facts.text: Three persons including the appellant were parcel porters at the railway station Manikpur in the district Banda of Uttar Pradesh.

anchor.surface_text: The facts are simple. Three persons including the appellant were, at the material time, parcel porters at the railway station Manikpur in the district Banda of Uttar Pradesh.

facts.text: On the night of 18th June 1952, three persons including appellant were found by two watchmen committing theft of packets of biscuits by breaking open a railway parcel.

anchor.surface_text: On the night of the 18th June, 1952, they were found by two watchmen of the Watch and Ward staff attached to the railway station, companymitting theft of certain packets of biscuits by breaking open a railway parcel

facts.text: First information lodged before the Sub-Inspector, Railway Police, by Ram Prasad, Head Watchman.

anchor.surface_text: companytaining those packets, which as parcel porters, they had occasion to handle. First information of the same was lodged, before the Sub-Inspector, Railway Police, by one Ram Prasad, Head Watchman.

facts.text: Railway Police filed charge-sheet under section 379 IPC on 20th June 1952.

anchor.surface_text: The Railway Police filed the charge-sheet under section 379 of the Indian Penal Code on the 20th June, 1952. The case was taken companynizance of by the Railway Magistrate, Manikpur.

facts.text: Railway Magistrate, Manikpur took cognizance of the case.

anchor.surface_text: The case was taken companynizance of by the Railway Magistrate, Manikpur. All the three accused pleaded guilty.

facts.text: All three accused pleaded guilty.

anchor.surface_text: All the three accused pleaded guilty. They were companyvicted by the Magistrate on the 15th July, 1952, and sentenced to a fine of Rs. 25 each.

facts.text: Three accused convicted by Magistrate on 15th July 1952 and sentenced to fine of Rs. 25 each.

anchor.surface_text: They were companyvicted by the Magistrate on the 15th July, 1952, and sentenced to a fine of Rs. 25 each. Against this companyviction the present appellant filed a revision

facts.text: Appellant filed revision to Sessions Judge of Banda arguing Railway Magistrate lacked jurisdiction under U.P. Panchayat Raj Act, 1947.

anchor.surface_text: Against this companyviction the present appellant filed a revision to the Sessions Judge of Banda. It is necessary at this stage to mention that under the U. P. Panchayat Raj Act, 1947, the Panchayati Adalats in U. P. have criminal jurisdiction in certain matters.

facts.text: Sessions Judge accepted contention of lack of jurisdiction and made reference to High Court to quash conviction and sentence.

anchor.surface_text: This companytention was accepted by the learned Sessions Judge. He accordingly made a reference to the High Court for quashing the companyviction 1447 and sentence.

facts.text: Single Judge of High Court declined to accept the reference on ground of discretionary revisional jurisdiction.

anchor.surface_text: It came before a Single Judge of the High Court who did number feel quite satisfied that the Railway Magistrate had jurisdiction. But without deciding the question one way or the other, he declined to accept the reference

facts.text: High Court Single Judge granted certificate for appeal to Supreme Court.

anchor.surface_text: Somewhat -curiously however, the learned Judge granted a certificate against his own judgment that the case is a fit one for appeal to the Supreme Court.

facts.text: Theft of property value Rs. 3.

anchor.surface_text: The charge-sheet filed by the police shows that the theft of the property involved in the case is Rs. 3.

facts.text: Offence committed within limits of Manikpur.

anchor.surface_text: There can also be numberdoubt that the offence has been companymitted within the limits of Manikpur.

facts.text: One of the three accused, Tulsi, belongs to Jubbalpore in Madhya Pradesh.

anchor.surface_text: But in the present case it is on the record that one-out of the three accused by name Tulsi belongs to Jubbalpore in Madhya Pradesh.

facts.text: U.P. Panchayat Raj Act, 1947 underwent amendments in 1952 and 1955, not applicable to this case.

anchor.surface_text: It may be mentioned that the Act appears to have undergone some amendments in the year 1952 and recently in 1955. These amendments have numberapplication to the present case.

facts.text: Railway Magistrate had jurisdiction to try the case.

anchor.surface_text: We are, therefore, of the opinion that the Railway Magistrate had the jurisdiction to try the case.

facts.text: Judgment delivered on March 15, 1955 by JAGANNADHADAS J.

anchor.surface_text: 1955. March 15. The Judgment of the Court was delivered by JAGANNADHADAS J.-This is an appeal by leave granted by the High Court of Allahabad

facts.text: Case is a police case.

anchor.surface_text: provided that in police cases -one Panch shall be such as may be residing in the Gaon Sabha in which the offence was companymitted

facts.text: No order passed by Sub-Divisional Magistrate under section 85.

anchor.surface_text: since it is,not suggested that there has been any order under section 85.

issues.text: Whether the Railway Magistrate had jurisdiction to try the case

anchor.surface_text: To decide the question of jurisdiction thus raised it is necessary to notice the scheme of the U. P. Panchayat Raj Act, 1947

issues.text: Whether rule 84 is valid insofar as it provides for exercise of jurisdiction over a resident outside the State with reference to section 49(4)

anchor.surface_text: But whether it is valid in so far as it provides for the exercise of jurisdiction in respect of a resident outside the State may be open to argument on more grounds than one. In the present case, it is sufficient to consider whether this portion of the rule is valid,

issues.text: Whether the trial of this case by the ordinary criminal Court is barred under section 55 of the Act
Whether the jurisdiction of the ordinary criminal court under section 5 CrPC is excluded where there is no valid machinery under the Panchayat Raj Act for trial of the case

arguments.claim: Railway Magistrate had no jurisdiction to try the case as it should have been tried by the Panchayati Adalat under the U.P. Panchayat Raj Act, 1947

anchor.surface_text: The point taken before the Sessions Judge was that by virtue of the said Act, the present case should have been tried by the Panchayati Adalat and that the Railway Magistrate had no jurisdiction. This contention was accepted by the learned Sessions Judge.

court_response_anchor.surface_text: e is companyprehensive. That section enjoins, that all offences under the Indian Penal Code shall be investigated, enquired into, tried and otherwise

arguments.court_reasoning: No valid bench could be constituted under section 49 due to one accused from outside the State; rule 84 ultra vires; no machinery to exclude ordinary court jurisdiction under section 5 CrPC

arguments.claim: Panchayati Adalat has jurisdiction prima facie under sections 51 and 52 as offence is theft of Rs. 3 within Manikpur limits

anchor.surface_text: The charge-sheet filed by the police shows that the theft of the property involved in the case is Rs. 3. There can also be no doubt that the offence has been committed within the limits of Manikpur.

arguments.claim: No bench can be constituted under section 49(2) as one accused Tulsi resides in Jubbalpore, Madhya Pradesh, outside any Gaon Sabha under the Act

anchor.surface_text: But in the present case it is on the record that one-out of the three accused by name Tulsi belongs to Jubbalpore in Madhya Pradesh. It was, therefore, not possible to constitute a bench in strict compliance with section 49 (2) of the Act to try his case.

arguments.claim: Rule 84 is ultra vires section 49(4) insofar as it provides for special benches including parties from outside the State
arguments.qualifiers: may be open to argument on more grounds than one

arguments.claim: Section 55 bar on cognizance applies to the 'case' as a whole under section 2(a), requiring trial of all accused together; impossible here without valid bench
Jurisdiction of ordinary criminal courts under section 5 CrPC is comprehensive and not excluded absent clear and operative limited jurisdiction machinery

anchor.surface_text: It is to be remembered that the jurisdiction of the criminal courts under section 5 of the Code of Criminal Procedure is comprehensive. ... Exclusion of jurisdiction of a court of general jurisdiction, can be brought about by the setting up of a court of limited jurisdiction ... only if the vesting and the exercise of that limited jurisdiction is clear and operative.

arguments.claim: Railway Magistrate had jurisdiction to try the case

anchor.surface_text: We are, therefore, of the opinion that the Railway Magistrate had the jurisdiction to try the case.

holdings.text: rule 84 in so far as it relates to the constitution of a special bench where one of the parties belongs to a place outside the State is ultra vires
holdings.reasoning_summary: Section 49(4) authorizes rules only for disputes between parties of different circles or Gaon Sabhas constituted under the Act; phrase 'for any other purpose' cannot extend to outsiders from beyond State

holdings.text: no competent bench could be constituted under section 49 of the Act for the trial of the present case in which there are three accused of whom one is a person belonging to a different State
holdings.reasoning_summary: Strict compliance with s49(2) impossible due to accused from outside State; special bench under invalid rule 84 unavailable

holdings.text: the bar which is brought about by section 55 relates to the case as a whole and requires valid machinery for trial of all accused together
holdings.reasoning_summary: S55 bars cognizance of 'case' defined under s2(a) as entire proceeding triable by Panchayati Adalat including bench; bar inoperative without machinery for whole case

holdings.text: Exclusion of jurisdiction of a court of general jurisdiction can be brought about by the setting up of a court of limited jurisdiction only if the vesting and the exercise of that limited jurisdiction is clear and operative
holdings.reasoning_summary: Jurisdiction under s5 CrPC comprehensive; limited jurisdiction under Panchayat Act excludes ordinary courts only where machinery fully operative for specific case

holdings.text: the Railway Magistrate had the jurisdiction to try the case

anchor.surface_text: We are, therefore, of the opinion that the Railway Magistrate had the jurisdiction to try the case.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Panchayati Adalat jurisdiction prima facie under ss51-52 but inoperative due to lack of valid bench for all accused; s55 bar not attracted; s5 CrPC applies
